title: Supply Chain Security
description: Comprehensive tutorials for software supply chain security including SBOM analysis, dependency confusion attacks, and artifact integrity verification.

steps.title: SBOM Fundamentals
steps.content:
OBJECTIVE: Learn SBOM concepts and generation techniques

STEP-BY-STEP PROCESS:
1. Install Syft: 'curl -sSfL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/anchore/syft/main/install.sh | sh'
2. Generate SBOM for a container: 'syft alpine:latest'
3. Analyze package dependencies
4. Check for vulnerable components
5. Export in multiple formats (JSON, SPDX, CycloneDX)

WHAT TO LOOK FOR:
- Package inventory completeness
- Version information accuracy
- License compliance data
- Vulnerability correlations
- Dependency tree depth

steps.title: SBOM-Based Vulnerability Scanning
steps.content:
OBJECTIVE: Use SBOM data for comprehensive vulnerability assessment

STEP-BY-STEP PROCESS:
1. Install Grype: 'curl -sSfL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/anchore/grype/main/install.sh | sh'
2. Scan SBOM with Grype: 'grype sbom:./sbom.json'
3. Analyze vulnerability matches
4. Check CVSS scores and exploitability
5. Generate remediation reports

WHAT TO LOOK FOR:
- Known vulnerability matches
- Severity classifications
- Exploit availability
- Patch availability
- False positive identification

steps.title: License Compliance Checking
steps.content:
OBJECTIVE: Analyze software licenses using SBOM data

STEP-BY-STEP PROCESS:
1. Extract license information from SBOM
2. Identify license conflicts
3. Check for copyleft licenses
4. Analyze license compatibility
5. Generate compliance reports

WHAT TO LOOK FOR:
- GPL/LGPL usage
- License compatibility issues
- Attribution requirements
- Commercial license restrictions
- Open source compliance gaps

steps.title: SBOM Quality Validation
steps.content:
OBJECTIVE: Evaluate SBOM completeness and accuracy

STEP-BY-STEP PROCESS:
1. Check SBOM metadata completeness
2. Validate package information
3. Assess relationship mappings
4. Test SBOM parsing tools
5. Compare against known good SBOMs

WHAT TO LOOK FOR:
- Missing package data
- Incomplete version info
- Broken relationship links
- Format validation errors
- Tool compatibility issues

steps.title: SBOM Automation & Monitoring
steps.content:
OBJECTIVE: Integrate SBOM generation into CI/CD pipelines

STEP-BY-STEP PROCESS:
1. Create automated SBOM generation scripts
2. Integrate with build pipelines
3. Set up SBOM storage and versioning
4. Implement continuous monitoring
5. Configure alerting for issues

WHAT TO LOOK FOR:
- Pipeline integration points
- Automation script reliability
- Storage security measures
- Monitoring effectiveness
- Alert threshold tuning

steps.title: Dependency Resolution Mechanics
steps.content:
OBJECTIVE: Learn how package managers resolve dependencies

STEP-BY-STEP PROCESS:
1. Examine npm package resolution: 'npm install lodash'
2. Check Python pip resolution process
3. Analyze Maven dependency resolution
4. Test package registry precedence
5. Understand version resolution algorithms

WHAT TO LOOK FOR:
- Registry search order
- Version matching rules
- Cache poisoning vectors
- Namespace conflicts
- Resolution algorithm weaknesses

steps.title: Dependency Confusion Exploitation
steps.content:
OBJECTIVE: Execute dependency confusion attacks against package managers

STEP-BY-STEP PROCESS:
1. Register malicious package with internal name
2. Publish to public registry with higher version
3. Trick internal systems into downloading malicious package
4. Execute payload in compromised environment
5. Maintain persistence through updates

WHAT TO LOOK FOR:
- Internal package name leaks
- Registry precedence exploitation
- Version manipulation
- Payload execution
- Update mechanism abuse

steps.title: Typosquatting Package Creation
steps.content:
OBJECTIVE: Create and deploy typosquatting packages

STEP-BY-STEP PROCESS:
1. Identify popular package names
2. Generate similar-sounding names (lodash â†’ loadsh)
3. Create malicious packages with typos
4. Publish to public registries
5. Monitor for installation attempts

WHAT TO LOOK FOR:
- Common typos in package names
- Similar character substitutions
- Package name variations
- Installation telemetry
- Attack success rates

steps.title: Registry Poisoning Methods
steps.content:
OBJECTIVE: Poison package registries with malicious content

STEP-BY-STEP PROCESS:
1. Compromise maintainer accounts
2. Inject malicious code into legitimate packages
3. Create fake package updates
4. Abuse registry APIs
5. Exploit CI/CD publishing workflows

WHAT TO LOOK FOR:
- Weak authentication mechanisms
- API abuse opportunities
- Publishing workflow vulnerabilities
- Update notification exploitation
- Social engineering vectors

steps.title: Supply Chain Attack Mitigation
steps.content:
OBJECTIVE: Implement defenses against dependency attacks

STEP-BY-STEP PROCESS:
1. Set up private package registries
2. Implement package signing
3. Use dependency locking (package-lock.json)
4. Deploy integrity checking
5. Monitor for anomalous packages

WHAT TO LOOK FOR:
- Registry isolation effectiveness
- Signature validation
- Lockfile integrity
- Anomaly detection accuracy
- Response time improvements

steps.title: Digital Signature Basics
steps.content:
OBJECTIVE: Understand digital signatures for software artifacts

STEP-BY-STEP PROCESS:
1. Generate GPG keypair: 'gpg --gen-key'
2. Sign a file: 'gpg --sign --armor file.txt'
3. Verify signature: 'gpg --verify file.txt.asc'
4. Check key trust levels
5. Understand certificate chains

WHAT TO LOOK FOR:
- Key generation best practices
- Signature verification process
- Trust model understanding
- Certificate validation
- Key management procedures

steps.title: Package Signing Workflows
steps.content:
OBJECTIVE: Implement signing for different package types

STEP-BY-STEP PROCESS:
1. Sign npm packages: 'npm publish --sign'
2. Sign Python wheels: 'python -m twine upload --sign dist/*'
3. Sign container images: 'cosign sign image:tag'
4. Verify signed packages
5. Set up automated signing

WHAT TO LOOK FOR:
- Package type support
- Signing workflow integration
- Verification procedures
- Automation reliability
- Key security measures

steps.title: Cryptographic Hash Verification
steps.content:
OBJECTIVE: Use cryptographic hashes for integrity verification

STEP-BY-STEP PROCESS:
1. Generate file hashes: 'sha256sum file.txt'
2. Create hash files for distributions
3. Implement hash verification in downloads
4. Use Merkle trees for large datasets
5. Automate integrity checking

WHAT TO LOOK FOR:
- Hash algorithm selection
- Collision resistance
- Verification speed
- Storage efficiency
- Automation integration

steps.title: Provenance Tracking
steps.content:
OBJECTIVE: Track artifact provenance through the supply chain

STEP-BY-STEP PROCESS:
1. Implement SLSA framework
2. Track build provenance
3. Verify build environments
4. Check dependency provenance
5. Generate provenance attestations

WHAT TO LOOK FOR:
- Build environment isolation
- Dependency chain tracking
- Attestation formats
- Verification procedures
- Compliance requirements

steps.title: Continuous Integrity Assurance
steps.content:
OBJECTIVE: Set up continuous integrity monitoring systems

STEP-BY-STEP PROCESS:
1. Deploy integrity scanners
2. Monitor artifact registries
3. Set up alerting for tampering
4. Implement automated remediation
5. Generate integrity reports

WHAT TO LOOK FOR:
- Detection accuracy
- False positive rates
- Response automation
- Reporting comprehensiveness
- System performance impact
